events.event_description: U.S. average gasoline prices are forecast to decrease by 11 cents per gallon (3%) in 2025 and further decrease by 18 cents per gallon (6%) in 2026 due to lower crude oil prices and increasing fleet fuel economy.
events.citation: We estimate U.S. average gasoline prices in 2025 will decrease by 11 cents per gallon (gal), or about 3%, compared with 2024. In 2026, we forecast a further decrease of about 18 cents/gal, or an additional 6%.

events.event_description: LyondellBasell's Houston refinery is expected to close in the first quarter of 2025, leading to reduced refinery production of gasoline and increased net imports.
events.citation: Our forecast for 2025 reflects our expectation for a small increase in U.S. gasoline consumption this year and increased net imports (imports minus exports) of motor gasoline to offset less refinery production of gasoline because of the expected closure of LyondellBasell's Houston refinery in the first quarter.

events.event_description: Phillips 66's Los Angeles refinery is planned to close at the end of 2025, which will contribute to decreased refinery production and increased net imports in 2026.
events.citation: We expect refinery production will also decrease in 2026 in response to the planned closure of Phillips 66's Los Angeles refinery at the end of 2025, contributing to further increases in net imports.

events.event_description: Rocky Mountain region gasoline prices are expected to remain flat in 2025 due to steady population growth and constrained production and transportation infrastructure.
events.citation: The Rocky Mountain prices effectively remain flat in 2025 because of steady regional population growth, contributing to increasing gasoline consumption, while constrained regional production and transportation infrastructure limits the ability to increase gasoline supply in response.

events.event_description: West Coast gasoline prices are forecast to increase in 2026 due to reduced regional production following the Phillips 66 refinery closure.
events.citation: On the West Coast, we expect limited increases in consumption but reduced regional production in 2026 because of the Phillips 66 refinery closure.
